text:
Madison Ave. North from 41st St.  1891
The New York Historical Society
170 Central Park West, New York City
Neg. No. 37042-A  Acc. No.
The following words must accompany any reproduction
of this photograph
"Courtesy of The New York Historical Society, New York City'

Madison Avenue, north from E. 41st Street. View 1 is inclusive, showing both sides of this arterial thoroughfare. From left to right appears, the Carbon Carbide Building (S. W. corner of 42nd St.), the Hotel Manhattan (which subsequently became the National City Building-N. W. corner) St. Bartholomew's P. E. Church (S. W. corner of 44th St.), The Brooks Bros. Building (N. W. corner), the Ritz-Carlton Hotel (46th to 47th Streets) and the Hotel Biltmore (east side, from 43rd to 44th Streets).
Views 2and3 are limited to the west frontage
between 41st and 42nd Streets. The modern structure at the right is the new Carbon Carbide Building at 42nd St. This
is to the left of View 1.
About 1914
Views 1,2,3
Gift of George H. Hahn
71 W. 35th St.

About 1914
Views 1,2,3

71 W. 35th St.

Madison Avenue at N.W. corner of 41st Street, the Fred F. French Building,nearing completion. In the background we have a glimpse of the New York Public Library.
September 1, 1920.
John Wallace Gillies, Photographer.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

Madison Avenue at S.E. corner of 41st Street, showing the old Thompson Mansion as remodelled for the use of the American Trust Company, after this the property was acquired by the American Trust Company and the New York Title and Mortgage Company, in January 1924.
In 1929 the Leftcourt Colonial Building will rise on this site.
By contrast with the picture of this corner about 1922, this view shows less of Madison Avenue and all of the south side of 41st Street east to the farther side of Park Avenue.  Note the Chemists' Club, 50-54 East 41st Street, also the old fashioned iron balconies and fire escape on the Murray Hill Hotel at the S.W. corner of Park Avenue and 41st Street.  Note also that Madison Avenue is temporarily a one-way street.
1924.
Edwin Levick, Photographer.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

297 Madison Avenue at S.E. Corner of 41st Street: the old Thompson Mansion in the block belonging to the Estate of Mary Clark Thompson. Prior to its occupation by Frederick Fox and Company it was used for a while by the Aero Club.
This picture should be compared with a later view (1924) showing the building remodelled, and also showing 277 Madison Avenue, adjoining, with the stoop removed.  In 1929 the two houses will be demolished, and the tower of the Lefcourt Colonial Building will rise from this corner.  The remainder of the block down to the corner of 40th Street, will be demolished in 1925.
About 1922
Morris Rosenfeld, Photographer.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

307 Madison Ave, east side, between 41st and 42nd Streets.
About 1919.Oh no, about 1926!.
Byron Company.

(1)
39, 41, 43, 45-53 East 41st Street, north side, between Madison and Park Avenues, shortly before demolition of No. 43 (the Athens Hotel) and No. 45-53 (The Lincoln Safe Deposit Company). The main entrance of these buildings is on 42nd street.
May 6, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg #2460
(2)
The same, also including the N.W. and N.E. corners of Park Avenue
May 6, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg #2461

41st Street, south side, from Madison to Lexington Avenues, inclusive.  The remodelled Thompson mansion on the corner, and the brownstone house adjoining it, are shown here shortly before demolition for the Lefcourt Colonial Building.
October 9, 1928

P. L. Sperr.

Madison Avenue, north from East 41st Street. 42nd Street is the intersecting thoroughfare in the
midground.
About 1928

Madison Avenue, east side, between 41st and 42nd Street, showing Nos. 303-05. These buildings will be replaced shortly afterwards by Madison Avenue wing of the Lincoln Building.
February 5, 1928.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

General View Midtown Manhattan, East 30As: Looking south from East 41st Street between Park (left) and Madison Avenues, across the rooftops of private homes and residential hotels. In the background are the towers of the Metropolitan (right)
and New York Life Insurance Buildings.
View 2 is southwestward across the roof of the Murray-Hill
Hotel.
View 3 is south on Fourth Avenue from East 32nd Street. The tall building is the New York Life; to its right is the
lower Flatiron Building.
P. L. Sperr  View 1,2: September 5, 1928
NO REPRODUCTIONS  View 3: February 27, 1931

1274/B3 : digitized
1264/B4 : digitized

Madison Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 4lst Street, showing a clearance at same, upon which 46-story structure was erected. This site included Nos. 295 and 297 Madison Ave., and 32 to 48 East 40th Street. On the left margin appears a clearance upon which the Lincoln Building will rise. The 21-story Hotel Belmont shown will be demolished shortly and the site will remain vacant in 1938. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
January 5, 1929.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.
